title: Divorce
intro:
Hypothesis: If two Christians get married, there are circumstances in which it would be lawful to divorce and marry someone else.

"Divorce" here may be understood as loosely as "separation" or as narrowly as "dissolution of a sacramental marriage", depending on your view of divorce. In practical terms, the question of whether divorce is possible or not is less pertinent than whether one who does leave a spouse is then allowed to remarry. This is related (but not identical) to the question of whether one is allowed to remarry after one's spouse dies, which is not included in this hypothesis.

evidence.head: Matthew's "Porneia" Exception
evidence.short: In the Gospel of Matthew, Jesus says that it is unlawful to divorce and remarry "except for 'porneia'".
evidence.details:
Porneia ('πορνεία') is generally translated as "sexual immorality". It is related to the word for "prostitute", "porne" ('πόρνη'), and can be said to refer to "prostitution and similar". Some less literal translations render it "unfaithfulness" or similar, but it should be noted that "adultery", "moicheia" ('μοιχεία'), is a different word.

Proponents argue that Jesus here means that one is allowed to divorce an unfaithful spouse and marry someone else. Some also argue that many Church Fathers use the terms "porneia" and "moicheia" interchangeably in their discussions and translations of the exception clause (with the Shepherd of Hermas being the earliest example).

Critics argue that Matthew is writing to a Jewish audience and is including an exception for unlawful marriages, meaning that if one "marries" one's sister or someone else's wife, then divorcing her is of course allowed because they aren't really married in the first place.

evidence.head: Mark: Jesus Forbids Divorce and Remarriage
evidence.short: The Gospel of Mark also records the discussion of divorce between Jesus and the Pharisees, but includes no exception clause.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that Jesus forbade divorce and remarriage here.

Proponents argue that Mark simply did not include details like the exception clause, but that this doesn't prove anything, because Matthew did.

evidence.head: Luke: Jesus Forbids Divorce and Remarriage
evidence.short: The Gospel of Luke also records the discussion of divorce with the Pharisees, and again includes no exception clause.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this is the second clear biblical prohibition on divorce and remarriage.

Proponents argue that although Luke did not include the exception, that doesn't mean Jesus didn't, because Matthew recorded it.

evidence.head: The Pauline Privilege: An Unbelieving Spouse Leaves
evidence.short: In his first letter to the Corinthians, St. Paul relays the command Jesus gave against divorce and remarriage, but allows remarriage if an unbelieving spouse leaves.
evidence.details:
Critics argue this is the third clear prohibition on divorce and remarriage for Christian couples, because the exception does not apply to two Christians.

Proponents argue that Paul did not include the exception from Matthew, but he included another one, which shows that not all exceptions are necessarily mentioned every time. Some also argue that it applies to an apostate who leaves.

evidence.head: Moses Allowed Divorce
evidence.short: The Law of Moses allowed a man to divorce his wife, and once she has been "defiled" by another, he couldn't take her back.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows that God allowed divorce and remarriage before, as also Jesus states, and that it is therefore not so strange that He might allow some exceptions now as well.

Critics argue that Jesus explained that this was because of the hardness of their hearts, and that it was not like this from the beginning, but Jesus came to restore God's plan for marriage by disallowing divorce.

evidence.head: Malachi: God Hates Divorce
evidence.short: Malachi says God made the husband and wife one flesh, and that He hates divorce.
evidence.details:
Critics point out that the passage even mentions unfaithfulness, suggesting that is not a good reason for divorce.

Proponents argue that divorce may not be ideal, but God still allowed it, and so unfaithfulness could still be an exception now.

evidence.head: Most Church Fathers Forbid Remarriage
evidence.short: Some Church Fathers are so strict that they even forbid remarriage after the death of a spouse, and even more so after a divorce.
evidence.details:
Critics take this to mean that the prohibition on remarriage after divorce is as old as the New Testament itself, with some Church Fathers seeking to "err on the side of caution" by being too restrictive.

Proponents generally agree that this is the general rule, and that these Church Fathers merely went too far in disallowing the exceptions.

St. Athenagoras (c. 176–177 AD): A Plea for the Christians, Chapter 33: https://www.logoslibrary.org/athenagoras/plea/33.html
Tertullian (c. 200 AD): To My Wife, Book II: https://tertullian.org/works/ad_uxorem.htm
Tertullian (c. 207–208 AD): Against Marcion, Book IV, Chapter 34: https://www.tertullian.org/articles/evans_marc/evans_marc_10book4_eng.htm
Clement of Alexandria (c. 199 AD – c.201 AD): Stromata, Chapter 23: https://www.earlychristianwritings.com/text/clement-stromata-book2.html

evidence.head: Lactantius: Remarriage For the Innocent Party?
evidence.short: Lactantius forbids divorce and remarriage for the guilty spouse in the case of adultery, although he can be interpreted as allowing the innocent party to remarry.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this is exactly what Matthew reports Jesus as allowing: if your wife commits adultery, you may divorce her and remarry, otherwise, you can't.

Critics argue that this permissive reading is not necessitated by the text, and that a more cautious reading is also possible.
references: Divine Institutes, Book VI, Chapter XXIII: https://ccel.org/ccel/lactantius/institutes/anf07.iii.ii.vi.xxiii.html (in Latin for some reason)
Divine Institutes, Book VI, Chapter XXIII: https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/07016.htm (in Latin for some reason)
The History of the Indissolubility of Marriage, page 260: https://ejournals.bc.edu/index.php/ctsa/article/view/2633/2281 (translation of the relevant passage)

evidence.head: The Catholic Church Holds to the Indissolubility of Marriage
evidence.short: The Catholic Church does not recognize any sort of divorce for a valid sacramental marriage.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this goes against Matthew's exception clause and can be disregarded.

Critics argue that the Catholic Church is the only church to take the biblical teaching of marriage seriously enough.

evidence.head: The Consent of the West
evidence.short: The Catholic Church holds sacramental marriage to be absolutely indissoluble, except by death of a spouse. Any attempted remarriage while a valid spouse is still alive is considered adultery.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this goes against Matthew's exception clause and can be disregarded.

Critics argue that the Catholic Church is the only church to take the biblical teaching of marriage seriously enough.

evidence.head: The Consent of the East
evidence.short: The Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Church, the Assyrian Church of the East, as well as most Protestant groups, all hold to the possibility of divorce and remarriage in certain circumstances, chiefly adultery.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this follows Matthew's exception clause.

Critics argue that it is an unjustified and overly permissive reading of the exception clause.
